items.description: Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
The risk of overtopping has passed as the tide is now falling. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area, although standing water and debris may remain.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
We will continue to monitor levels closely

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 17:45 on 11/09/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 10 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 16:00 on 11/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Thursday's early morning tide at 01:00 on 11/09/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days, and accompanied by strong Westerly Force 6 winds. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.16 metres. The total forecast tide is 6.15 metres Chart Datum (3.1 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides being lower, only minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will reissue this Flood Alert if property flooding could be possible.

items.description: Thorney Island to West Itchenor

Over the next five days, light winds and small waves are forecast, and with tides being lower, only minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast over the coming days. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
First forecast high-water is 9:00 PM on 10/09/25 with a level of 7.86 mAOD,  a Force 5 westerley direction and second forecast high-water is 9:15 AM on 11/09/25 with a level of 7.38 mAOD and a Force 4 South-westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
Further flooding is possible at high-water until Thursday due to higher than normal tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will be closing flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
We do not anticipate the flood alert level to be met during this afternoon’s high tide.
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 12/09/2025.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, 11/09/2025, by 5:00 PM, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a result of high spring tides until Friday morning.

Please avoid driving through flood water and do not put yourself or others at risk.

We will update this message by 3pm on Thursday 11th September 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 11/09/2025.
Flooding is possible around the high tide tonight at 01:00AM on 11/09/2025 with high water levels 2 hours either side.

We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
Flooding is possible between 9:15 - 11:00am on Friday 12/09/2025. High tides, strong winds and large waves tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are coastal roads and footpaths around Spurn Point. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are in a period of high astronomic tides with unsettled weather conditions for the next few days, so this alert may be re-issued if required. 

This message will be updated by 9:00pm on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a result of high spring tides peaking this evening and tomorrow morning. Tides will be at their highest tonight around 22:30 10/09/2025.
 Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tide.

Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 

Predicted peaks:- Sharpness 9.9m to 10.2m at 22:30 on 10/09/2025.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated  by 13:00 on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tweed estuary
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Tidal conditions are expected to improve this morning and no flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
The threat of flooding from this morning's high tide has now passed. Higher than normal water levels are expected along the Tyne Estuary again tomorrow morning, Friday 12/09/2025, between 5:00 AM and 7:00 AM due to high tides. The peak level at Newcastle Quayside is expected to be between 3.1 and 3.2 mAOD. We will continue to monitor forecasts closely, however at this stage, no property flooding is anticipated.
 
Please be careful along riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads which may be flooded.
 
This message will be updated or removed by 10:00 AM on 12/09/2025.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: The unsettled weather which brought elevated tide levels along the South Coast has now cleared the area. This afternoon’s tide (on 10/09/2025 at 14:00) at Portsmouth, came in only 2cm over forecast. Tide levels will remain high until Friday afternoon (12/09/2025), before moving towards their neap phase. Therefore, no further Flood Alerts will be necessary during this period.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 1:45pm and 3:45pm today, Thursday 11th September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.71mAODN at 2:45pm on Thursday 11th September, which is actually 0.03m below tide tables, wind Force 5, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 5:00pm today, Thursday 11th September

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message: The high tide this evening, Wednesday, may lead to flooding of roads and low lying land, but property flooding is not expected. Highest tide level is expected at coastal areas at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour at 9:30 PM this evening, 10/09/2025. Flooding is possible for up to an hour either side of this time. Areas most at risk include coastal areas at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. The detailed tidal forecast is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 6.83 mAODN at 9:30 PM on 10/09/2025, with westerly force 5 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level. There may be further tides that require this flood alert. All times are to British Summer Time. This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
The high tide this evening, Wednesday, may lead to flooding of roads and low lying land, but property flooding is not expected. Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade at 10:00 PM this evening, 10/09/2025. Flooding is possible for an hour either side of this time. Areas most at risk include the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.86 mAODN at 10:00 PM on 10/09/2025, with westerly force 5 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level. There may be further tides that require this flood alert. All times are to British Summer Time. This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.86 mAODN at 10:00 PM on 10/09/2025, with westerly force 5 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A flood alert has been issued as a result of an ongoing period of high tides. Tides will be at their highest between 20:45 on 08/09/25 and 22:00 Wednesday, 10/09/25. Flooding to roads and low lying land adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the times of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides.
Predicted peaks at Newport 7.7m at 22:00 on 10/09/2025 and 7.2m at 10:15 on 11/09/2025.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 13:00 on 11/09/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Camel Estuary at Rock and low lying properties on the Little Petherick Creek
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Cornwall Coast, Tidal Camel Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water at Padstow is at 7:59pm, times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Strong force 5 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 3m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed areas. 

Locations particularly at risk include Little Petherick.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and update by Thursday afternoon.  

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Padstow is 4.35 mAOD, this is 0.2 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
A flood warning has been issued as a result of high spring tides peaking this evening and tomorrow morning. Tides will be at their highest between 22:00 today 10/09/2025 and 10:15 tomorrow 11/09/2025. 
Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tide. High tides may impact properties and roads in and around Brockweir on the Wye Estuary. 

Predicted peaks:- 

Avonmouth Portbury 7.7m to 8m on 10/09/2025 at 22:00. 
Newport 7.4m to 7.7m on 10/09/2025 at 22:00.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 13:00 on 11/09/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Irish Sea from Hilbre Island to Heswall
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast for the early hours of Thursday 11/09/2025. 
Spray overtopping and flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 00:00 AM on 11/09/2025. 
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level not to be met during the next high tide at around midday 11/09/2025. 
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: The high tide this evening, Wednesday, may lead to flooding of roads and low lying land, but property flooding is not expected. The highest tide level is forecast between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir at 9:30 PM this evening, 10/09/2025. Flooding is possible for up to an hour either side of these times. The area most at risk is the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. We are closely monitoring the situation. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Be careful along coastal areas such as paths and low lying roads. The detailed tidal forecast is based on the peak level at Hinkley Point. The forecast high water is at 9:30 PM on 10/09/2025 with a level of 6.83 mAODN and westerly force 5 winds. mAODN is height above average sea level. There may be further tides that require this flood alert in the coming days. All times are to British Summer Time. This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 11/09/2025, or as the situation changes.
